content:
Certainly! Here are some sake options that could be added to the wine list:

1. Junmai: This is a pure rice sake made without the addition of distilled alcohol. Some good options include:
* Dassai 39 Junmai Daiginjo, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
* Urakasumi Junmai, Miyagi Prefecture, Japan
* Tedorigawa Yamahai Junmai, Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan
2. Ginjo: This is a premium sake made with highly polished rice and the addition of a small amount of distilled alcohol. Some good options include:
* Nanbu Bijin Tokubetsu Junmai Ginjo, Iwate Prefecture, Japan
* Dewazakura Oka Ginjo, Yamagata Prefecture, Japan
* Kikusui Junmai Ginjo, Niigata Prefecture, Japan
3. Nigori: This is an unfiltered sake with a milky appearance and a sweet, creamy flavor. Some good options include:
* Tozai Snow Maiden Nigori, Kyoto Prefecture, Japan
* Yuki No Bosha Nigori, Akita Prefecture, Japan
* Mio Sparkling Sake, Hyogo Prefecture, Japan

Sake is a traditional Japanese beverage made from fermented rice. It can have a wide range of flavors and aromas, from light and delicate to rich and full-bodied. Sake is typically served chilled or at room temperature, and can be enjoyed on its own or paired with a variety of foods, including sushi, sashimi, and other Japanese cuisine.
